875914030.given_title: The Role of Wind in a Tree’s Life
875914030.resolved_title: The Role of Wind in a Tree's Life
875914030.excerpt: Remember the biosphere 2? In short, it’s a miniature version of our planet, now owned by the university of Arizona, constructed for scientists to study how the planet’s living systems actually work.

2446278850.given_title: The Mysterious Life (and Death) of Africa’s Oldest Trees
2446278850.excerpt: On the plight of the baobab tree.

1889525944.resolved_title: Can American soil be brought back to life?
1889525944.excerpt: A new idea: If we revive the tiny creatures that make dirt healthy, we can bring back the great American topsoil. But farming culture — and government — aren't making it easy.

1.caption: Soil health experts say that leaving the ground bare between rows of crops, as in this corn field in Illinois, increases topsoil erosion and runoff of fertilizers and other chemicals into water supplies. | Getty Images

2.caption: Farmers have tilled soil for generations, turning it over to bury weeds and loosen the ground for seeds. But it turns out that tilling, as on this farm in Maryland, top, kills many of the microorganisms that can keep soil healthy and productive. The result is arid and degraded topsoil that easily succumbs to drought. like the soil on a Kansas farm, bottom. | Getty

3.caption: Rye grass planted between rows of corn is one example of cover-cropping, a technique that keeps soil from eroding and replenishes its nutrients. | Wikimedia Commons

1990421072.resolved_title: From the memories of flowers to the sociability of trees, the cognitive capacities of our vegetal cousins are all around us
1990421072.excerpt: At first glance, the Cornish mallow (Lavatera cretica) is little more than an unprepossessing weed. It has pinkish flowers and broad, flat leaves that track sunlight throughout the day. However, it’s what the mallow does at night that has propelled this humble plant into the scientific spotlight.

3718284061.resolved_title: Phantom Forests: Why Ambitious Tree Planting Projects Are Failing
3718284061.excerpt: It was perhaps the most spectacular failed tree planting project ever. Certainly the fastest. On March 8, 2012, teams of village volunteers in Camarines Sur province on the Filipino island of Luzon sunk over a million mangrove seedlings into coastal mud in just an hour of frenzied activity.

1.credit: CHAIDEER MAHYUDDIN / AFP via Getty Images

A villager in Peukan Bada, Indonesia plants mangrove trees.
          CHAIDEER MAHYUDDIN / AFP via Getty Images

2.credit: WANG JIANG / VCG VIA GETTY IMAGES
2.caption:
Volunteers plant trees at the edge of China's Badain Jaran Desert last year.
          WANG JIANG / VCG VIA GETTY IMAGES

4.caption:
Trees blackened by the 2021 Bootleg Fire in Oregon, which burned through woodlands providing Microsoft with carbon offsets.
          Nathan Howard / AP

6.caption:
More than 9,000 people in Leh, India planted more than 50,000 tree saplings in under an hour on October 10, 2010.
      Drukpa Publications via Wikipedia

3728226359.resolved_title: Meet Nature’s Apex Regenerator: The Mighty Baobab Tree
3728226359.excerpt: The oldest relationship between humans and ancient trees naturally occurs in Africa. The continent’s longest-lived tree is the largest, too. Amazingly wide for its height, a mature baobab appears otherworldly.

3345063911.given_title: The American West's sagebrush sea is rapidly vanishing
3345063911.resolved_title: The American West's sagebrush sea is rapidly vanishing
3345063911.excerpt: The big sagebrush is far from your typical tumbleweed. In the dry landscape of the American West, the sun catches the plant’s fine silver hair like light reflecting off a stormy ocean. Growing as tall as your thigh, their lanky limbs seem frozen in a permanently petrified stance.

1.caption: A closeup of a sagebrush's narrow segmented leaves reveals its tiny silver hairs

2.credit: Tom Koerner/U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service on Flickr (Public Domain)
2.caption: Greater sage-grouse thrives in sagebrush habitats

3.credit: Tom Koerner/U.S. Fish and Wildlifeon Flickr (CC  2.0)
3.caption: Sagebrush habitat is diminishing at an accelerated rate from mining and energy development, cropland conversion, invasive grasses, and increased wildfires

3509024167.given_title: The Strange Quest to Save North America’s Most Elusive Oak Tree
3509024167.resolved_title: The Strange Quest to Save North America’s Most Elusive Oak Tree
3509024167.excerpt: There was perhaps no one better than Cornelius H. Muller—one of twentieth-century America’s most notable oak fanatics—to document the continent’s most mysterious oak trees.

2453352506.given_title: Arborists Are Bringing the 'Dinosaur of Trees' Back To Life
2453352506.resolved_title: Arborists Are Bringing the 'Dinosaur of Trees' Back To Life
2453352506.excerpt: Arborists are cloning saplings from the stumps of the world's largest, strongest, and longest-lived trees -- felled for timber more than a century ago -- to create redwood "super groves" that can help fight climate change.

3650982169.resolved_title: Mapping Urban Trees Across North America with the Auto Arborist Dataset
3650982169.excerpt: Over four billion people live in cities around the globe, and while most people interact daily with others — at the grocery store, on public transit, at work — they may take for granted their frequent interactions with the diverse plants and animals that comprise fragile urban ecosystems.

1.caption: Census data is typically not comprehensive, covering a subset of public trees and not including those in parks.

2.caption: The 23 cities in the dataset are spread across North America, and are categorized into West, Central, and East regions to enable analysis of spatial and hierarchical generalization.

3.credit: which is never seen during training in any capacity
3.caption: The number of tree records and genera in the dataset, per city and per region. The holdout city

4.credit: using a model trained on Open Images
4.caption: Selected Street View imagery from the Auto Arborist dataset. Green boxes represent tree detections

5.caption: The long-tailed distribution across Auto Arborist categories. Most examples come from a few frequent categories, and many categories have far fewer examples. We characterize each genus as frequent, common, or rare based on the number of training examples. Note that the test data is split spatially from the training data within each city, so not all rare genera are seen in the test set.

6.caption: The performance on each city’s test set when training on itself, on the region, and on the full training set.

7.caption: Cross-set performance, looking at the pairwise combination of train and test sets for each city. Note the block-diagonal structure, which highlights regional structure in the dataset.

3354668169.resolved_title: The Deep Roots of the Vegetable That ‘Took Over the World’
3354668169.excerpt: Stray dogs, “wacky” genes, and a deep affection that inspires “blasphemous” poetry. The plant known as Brassica rapa has quite the history, one that, after decades of debate, is finally emerging.

1.caption: A field of northwestern Spain's beloved grelos is just one of the many permutations of Brassica rapa. el Buho nº30, CC BY-SA 2.0/flickr

2.caption: Domesticated in Japan, mizuna is the same species as turnips, bok choy, and many other popular B. rapa crops. Toshimasa Ishibashi, CC BY 2.0/flickr

3.caption: Domestication of wild Brassica rapa likely occurred first in the Hindu Kush of Central Asia. lensnmatter, CC BY 2.0/FLICKR

4.caption: Genetic research indicates that the turnip was likely the first Brassica rapa crop, originating up to 6,000 years ago in Central Asia. Franco Folini, CC BY-SA 2.0/flickr

3360072677.given_title: The birthplace of the modern apple - BBC Travel
3360072677.resolved_title: The birthplace of the modern apple
3360072677.excerpt: Winter’s cool indifference had already embraced the snow-tipped peaks of the Tian Shan mountain system, winds whispering the tall trees into a state of undress. After driving for about two hours to the Turgen Gorge, we abandoned the vehicle and continued on foot.

1.caption: The foothills of the Tian Shan mountains in Kazakhstan were once blanketed with Malus sieversii trees

2.caption: The Malus sieversii has been identified as the progenitor of the domestic apple

3.caption: Silk Road trade brought the apple from Kazakhstan to Europe, China and, eventually, North America

4.caption: Almaty used to be called Alma-Ata, meaning ‘father of apples’

5.caption: Today, images of apples can be found all around Almaty

6.caption: Although apples feature prominently in Kazakh cuisine, the Malus sieversii is currently listed as ‘vulnerable’ on the ICUN Red List

3792978316.resolved_title: A journey to Earth's most remote flower
3792978316.excerpt: It was Fiji Day in Suva, the compact capital of the island-nation of Fiji and the South Pacific's largest city. Near a parked taxi draped in light-blue national flags, I turned left off Victoria Parade and into Albert Park.

1.caption: The tagimoucia only grows on one of Fiji's 330 islands, Taveuni

2.caption: A ferry whisks travellers from Savusavu to the island of Taveuni

3.caption: Amoreena and Tabua Tikoilawaqa are originally from the island of Qamea

4.caption: Village elders recommend hiring a guide for anyone trying to see the tagimoucia

5.caption: The tagimoucia represents a sort of Fijian Romeo and Juliet that has captured the country's imagination

6.caption: Locals say it always rains along the trail to see the tagimoucia

7.caption: Some say the scent of tagimoucia lingers on Qamea

3834759494.excerpt: In the 1970s, the Indonesian island of Bali went through a period of rapid change. Along the stunning beaches on the southern side of the island, tourism boomed. Parking lots were put up, together with swinging hot spots and hotels of various colours.

3511635244.excerpt: For the past four years, between the months of December and March, Seth Angerer has walked through his family’s orchard in Geyserville, Calif., hoping for a miracle. With his dogs Leo and Vito in tow, he walks the 8 acres, slowly making his way up and down the rows of hazelnut trees.

3745050023.resolved_title: The Beautiful, Brutal World of Bonsai
3745050023.excerpt: In the winter of 2002, a young American named Ryan Neil joined an unusual pilgrimage: he and several others flew to Tokyo, to begin a tour of Japan’s finest collections of bonsai trees. He was nineteen, with an athlete’s body and a sunny, symmetrical face.

1.caption: Ryan Neil, with a bonsai that he styled at his garden, outside Portland, Oregon. Neil studied the art in Japan for six years.Photograph by Suzanne Saroff for The New Yorker

2.caption: Masahiko Kimura, the so-called magician of bonsai, is widely regarded as the field’s most innovative living figure.Photograph by Toshiki Senoue

3.caption: A bonsai sculpted by Kimura, who uses power tools to perform transformations so drastic that the resulting shapes seem almost impossible.Photograph by Toshiki Senoue

4.caption: “There’s no need to howl at every moon we pass by.”

5.credit: Photograph  Suzanne Saroff for The New Yorker
5.caption: A limber pine sculpted by Neil, whose style is less groomed than Kimura’s. Like many bonsai artists, Neil uses copper wire to manipulate branches, but he is careful not to mar a “natural sculpture” for the sake of convention.Photograph by Suzanne Saroff for The New Yorker

4015603531.given_title: The Extraordinary Lives Of Coast Redwoods
4015603531.resolved_title: The Extraordinary Lives Of Coast Redwoods
4015603531.excerpt: The big coast redwoods (Sequoia sempervirens) are magnificent, like news from another world. A few individuals grow to just shy of 400 feet, making them the tallest carbon-bearing organisms on Earth. We still don’t know why they get so high, nor why they’re not even taller.

3207652572.excerpt: Mistletoes have all but shut down the powerhouses of their cells. Scientists are still trying to understand the plants’ unorthodox survival strategy. Holiday-season traditions stretching back for centuries have linked wintertime romance to decorative sprigs of mistletoe.

1.caption:
During the holiday season, sprigs of mistletoe appear everywhere as traditional decorations. Scientists have recently discovered a metabolic quirk of mistletoes that sets them apart from all other multicellular life.


Nigel Cattlin / Science Source

Although the analysis is complicated, the logic is simple: The element strontium comes in different weights, called isotopes.

3045524733.excerpt: Botanist Wesley Knapp has a reputation for finding lost plants. Now Knapp has contributed to a new discovery—the identity of a plant species that’s been hiding under experts’ eyes and noses for decades.
